p: Having seen a greater increase in T cell numbers in the airways (BAL), T cells within the lungs were analysed in more detail at various time points after infection. As seen in the airway, the number of CD8 T cells within the lungs of infected BTE sensitised mice were very low on day 4 p.i., but rose rapidly peaking on day 8 p.i., much earlier and significantly higher than the peak seen in infected PBS mice which occurred at day 11 p.i. ( Fig 4G). In addition, an increase in the frequency and number of influenza NP-specific CD8 T cells ( Fig 4H and 4I) and CD8 T cells producing IFN-γ ( Fig 4J) was also seen at day 8 p.i. in infected BTE sensitised compared to infected PBS treated mice. This earlier increase in CD8 T cells in infected BTE sensitised mice was accompanied by a quicker decline in CD8 T cells in the lungs and by day 14 p.i. the number of CD8 T cells was significantly lower compared to infected PBS treated mice ( Fig 4G). This was also reflected in the number of CD8 T cells producing IFN-γ at day 14 p.i. ( Fig 4J). Concomitant with the early increase in CD8 T cells a similar pattern was observed for CD4 T cells, with significantly higher numbers of CD4 T cells ( Fig 4K) seen at day 4 and day 8 p.i. in infected BTE sensitised mice compared to infected PBS treated mice. A similar number of CD4 T cells producing IFN-γ were found in both infected BTE sensitised and PBS treated mice between day 4 and 11 p.i. However, at day 14 p.i. a significant increase was seen in infected PBS treated mice compared to infected BTE sensitised mice ( Fig 4L).
